user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_polling_thread:
```c
static MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_ MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_
MHD_polling_thread (void *cls)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = cls;
#ifdef HAVE_PTHREAD_SIGMASK
  sigset_t s_mask;
  int err;
#endif /* HAVE_PTHREAD_SIGMASK */

  MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_current_thread_ID_ (&(daemon->tid));
#ifdef HAVE_PTHREAD_SIGMASK
  if ((0 == sigemptyset (&s_mask)) &&
      (0 == sigaddset (&s_mask, SIGPIPE)))
  {
    err = pthread_sigmask (SIG_BLOCK, &s_mask, NULL);
  }
  else
    err = errno;
  if (0 == err)
    daemon->sigpipe_blocked = true;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  else
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to block SIGPIPE on daemon thread: %s\n"),
              MHD_strerror_ (errno));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
#endif /* HAVE_PTHREAD_SIGMASK */
  while (! daemon->shutdown)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_POLL
    if (MHD_D_IS_USING_POLL_ (daemon))
      MHD_poll (daemon, MHD_YES);
    else
#endif /* HAVE_POLL */
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
    if (MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_ (daemon))
      MHD_epoll (daemon, -1);
    else
#endif
    MHD_select (daemon, -1);
    MHD_cleanup_connections (daemon);
  }

  /* Resume any pending for resume connections, join
   * all connection's threads (if any) and finally cleanup
   * everything. */
  if (0 != (MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME & daemon->options))
    resume_suspended_connections (daemon);
  close_all_connections (daemon);

  return (MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I flagged fragments that can be statically or logically unreachable depending on compile-time macros or runtime conditions: (1) the thread-ID set call (first line) could be unreachable if cls/daemon is NULL — worth checking usage assumptions and caller contract; (2) the entire HAVE_PTHREAD_SIGMASK block contains multiple conditional branches and nested #ifdef/#ifdef-ed else clauses which can produce dead/unsupported branches or dangling else combinations depending on macro configuration; (3) the polling/epoll/select sequence mixes preprocessor conditionals with else clauses across #ifdef boundaries — this pattern can lead to branches that are never compiled or that create mismatched else/if pairs, so should be reviewed for unreachable code under different build configurations; (4) the while (! daemon->shutdown) loop followed by cleanup/return: if daemon->shutdown can never become true in some configurations or usage patterns, the cleanup code and return become unreachable at runtime. Other fragments in the function (local declarations, simple assignments, single-line calls such as MHD_cleanup_connections (daemon); and the final return statement themselves are straightforward and do not by themselves constitute statically unreachable code, so they were not flagged. I concentrated on fragments where preprocessor combinations or program logic can produce unreachable code paths that should be investigated for MISRA Rule 2.1 compliance.
